awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Measurement, Analysis, and Novel Applications of Blockchains
awd_abstract_narration:
This research seeks to develop the science of blockchains. A blockchain is a distributed append-only database containing cryptographically linked records. The technology is the basis of cryptocurrencies (e.g., bitcoin). Principled methods for analyzing blockchain data will be developed in order to answer key questions about the economics, security, privacy, and anonymity of cryptocurrencies. The project envisions blockchains as the pillar of a new breed of decentralized applications and Internet security mechanisms. The project will develop a new open-source blockchain analysis tool, BlockSci, and use it to answer research questions including: How should we model cryptocurrency participants? How well do decentralized markets work, and how do they fail? How private are cryptocurrencies in practice? Can blockchains serve as the foundation for a secure, decentralized Internet? The research outputs of the project will be integrated into Princeton's Massive Online Open Course on cryptocurrencies, student projects, and a new course on the economics of security. The project will inform the cryptocurrency industry and developer community through conferences and release of open-source software.

This project will combine computer science research on cryptocurrencies with cutting-edge techniques from game theory and mechanism design. The project could validate the applicability of powerful machine learning methods, including spectral graph analysis, to the rich data in blockchains. The system design and deployment component will contribute to important ongoing debates on the different approaches to scaling of big data analytics techniques. The PI will continue his engagement with policy makers and regulators to ensure that government agencies are informed by the results of this project.

por.por_cntn:
Modern cryptocurrencies operate by storing a record of all transactions on public ledgers called blockchains. Bitcoin?s blockchain alone has hundreds of gigabytes of transaction data, and there are hundreds of other cryptocurrencies. This provides researchers with a public corpus of financial transactions on a scale that has never before been possible. It can help answer questions about the privacy, anonymity, and economics of cryptocurrencies.

BlockSci: blockchain analysis software. Yet, before this project, this potential remained mostly untapped because of the practical difficulty of analyzing blockchain data. To address this, the project created open-source software called BlockSci which enables the science of blockchains. It contains many innovations: a unified representation of blockchain data that allows a single programming interface across many different blockchains; an optimized data representation that allows it to operate entirely in memory, which is orders of magnitude faster than those that use disk storage; and a programmer interface that provides the expressivity of high-level code without sacrificing the performance benefits of low-level code.

BlockSci has been widely adopted for research, by over 40 papers and research projects as of this writing, both within and outside academia. It has been ?forked? (that is, has had derivative software created) 250 times on GitHub, an open-source software repository. BlockSci is accompanied by a peer-reviewed research paper at the 2020 Usenix Security Symposium describing its design and applications. 

Privacy and forensics. Through a series of papers that analyzed publicly available blockchain data using BlockSci, the project showed the privacy risks of cryptocurrencies. For example, if a user pays online using a cryptocurrency, hidden third-party trackers that are present on web pages typically possess enough information about the purchase to uniquely identify the transaction on the blockchain, link it to the user?s cookie, and further to the user?s real identity. The project also showed vulnerabilities in the privacy mechanisms of Monero and Dash, two prominent privacy-focused cryptocurrencies.

However, the same weaknesses that diminish privacy for everyday users of cryptocurrencies also make it easier to conduct forensic analysis of illicit activity enabled by cryptocurrencies, such as thefts or ransomware payments. The project showed how to carry out blockchain forensics effectively using BlockSci. Notably, new techniques using machine learning make it possible to cluster together the addresses (pseudo-identities) belonging to the same entity; address clustering is the bedrock of blockchain forensics. The project also explored design changes to blockchains that could allow regulation and transaction tracing without compromising privacy.

Other outputs. The project included a few other research directions. One was a mathematical analysis of how cryptocurrencies will behave if each participant acted according to their own incentives. One conclusion was that ?proof-of-stake? cryptocurrencies that do away with energy-intensive ?mining? are less secure than previously thought. Another paper proposed a way to make cryptocurrency wallets more secure by securely splitting the cryptographic key (that controls ownership of coins) among different locations. 

On the education front, PI Narayanan offered a popular online course on Bitcoin and cryptocurrency technologies that has had over half a million active learners. Narayanan also periodically provided advice to policy makers and regulators throughout the lifetime of the project.
